awd_titl_txt: Overcoming Barriers for Transfer Students in the Engineering Pipeline
awd_abstract_narration:
The scholarship program in the College of Engineering at the University of Massachusetts Amherst will increase the number of community college students with demonstrated academic talent and financial need who transfer, complete baccalaureate degrees in engineering, and enter the STEM workforce. The project will begin with the recruitment of a group of 22 new community college transfer students. The selected students, to be known as S-STEM Scholars, will receive up to $6,000 per year in scholarships and participate in a comprehensive program of academic, professional and personal support. Nearly half of the students who earn baccalaureate degrees in science and engineering in the US complete part of their education at a community college. Programs designed to support community college students to transition to, and graduate from, four-year engineering programs will increase the number of engineering graduates entering the workforce. Scholarships for academically strong engineering students, who may not otherwise be able to afford college, will increase the number of engineering graduates prepared to promote innovation and competiveness in national and regional technology-intensive industries.

The enrichment and support programs build upon effective practices known to help increase retention and degree completion among community college students that transfer to four-year baccalaureate degree programs. The program will include activities to promote faculty-student interaction, offer both peer-to-peer and industry mentoring through a Connect for Success Mentoring Network, provide several workshops focused on academic success, and deliver a suite of career development workshops customized for the S-STEM Scholars. This program design will help to overcome known barriers to persistence of transfer students from community college.  These barriers are lack of engagement on campus, underdeveloped professional identity and career goals, incomplete study habits, fewer opportunities to gain practical competence, and the need to earn money through non-academically related work. Assessment and evaluation will provide insight into the retention benefits of student scholarships, learning communities, career development activities, and faculty mentoring/advising. Lessons learned and effective practices that emerge from the program evaluation data will be disseminated widely to the engineering education community and help enlarge the knowledge base regarding attributes and practices of successful scholarship programs of this type.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the UMass Amherst S-STEM Grant entitled "Overcoming Barriers for Transfer Students in Engineering" was to increase the number of well-educated and skilled engineers by supporting community college students during their transition to UMass and through graduation. The grant supported 52 transfer students from 11 community colleges (CCs) pursuing degrees in six of our seven engineering majors. At the time of the grant, our seventh major, biomedical engineering, was a new program which did not accept transfer students. The cohort was 84.6% male and 15.4% female. In terms of ethnicity, 57.5% of the students self-reported as white, 13.5% as Asian, 11.5% as Black, 1.9% as Native Hawaiian/Pacific Islander, 1.9% multi-racial (asian-white), and 13.5% chose to not report. In addition, 5.7% identified as Hispanic and 3.8% reported a disability. Many students in the cohort were older students returning to school from a long absence, needing to re-acclimate to the academic environment and find a learning support group amongst a much younger population. Other challenges faced by our cohort included the loss of one or both parents, challenging health issues and balancing school with the care of young children. Financial, academic, professional and personal support from the program were key factors in their successful graduation with a bachelor?s degree in STEM. Of the 52 students, 40 have graduated (two from non-engineering majors but related STEM fields), 3 are on track to graduate in the next 9 months, and 9 left the University for various reasons. Of the 38 graduated with engineering degrees, 31 are working in STEM fields, 1 pursuing an advanced degree, and the other 6 were still looking when last reported. 

Several outcomes of the grant will have long-lasting impacts for future transfer students from community colleges.

 (1) Stronger ties were established between the College and our regional CCs, which are being leveraged to connect students with engineering before they transfer. For example, a mentor program links community college students with UMass students who transferred from the same institution. While this initiative is currently funded by another grant, the College has committed continued support. Similarly, positions have been established in several of our engineering student organizations for liaisons from the community colleges.

(2) Per requests from the CCs, the College plans to host two Community College Days, inviting CC students and faculty to campus to meet with our students and faculty, tour facilities, and shadow a student for the day, providing a much more engineering centric visit than previous such events. Our plans for this event the last two years have been derailed by COVID. 

(3) A professional support seminar for transfer students has been institutionalized through the Engineering Office of Student Affairs.

(4) The Engineering Office of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion has taken ownership of support services such as transfer student family dinners, alumni panels, meet and greets, and supplemental coaching.

(5) Our individual departments have addressed curricular barriers which made it difficult for CC transfer students in some majors to graduate within two years of transferring with their Associate Degree. Still underway are efforts to connect faculty to ensure synergy between content covered in core courses at the CC and expected learning outcomes from the same classes taught at UMass.

(6) Through a partnership with Massachusetts Department of Higher Education (MA DHE) and our regional CCs, a bridge program for transfer students to three of our STEM colleges, including engineering, was established and successfully run the past three summers. Students take their required junior year writing course at UMass the summer prior to transferring full time. As part of the class, students are mentored and introduced to people and resources across UMass. Students receive a small stipend upon successful completion of the course, and support services continue once they arrive on campus full time in the fall. The program has been very successful and is anticipated to grow through continued support by MA DHE.

(7) We have partnered with our regional CCs to support their grant writing efforts and initiatives, which will lead to new opportunities and additional support mechanisms. One such proposal was recently awarded.

(8) An Engineering Engagement Specialist has been added to the Engineering Office of DEI to, in part, support transfer student initiatives.

(9) The course Engin 391W - Mindfulness and Wellness in Engineering - was designed in collaboration with faculty in the College of Nursing specifically to serve our S-STEM Scholars. This class will continue to be offered through the Engineering Office of DEI.

(10) We institutionalized several internal technical workshops that had been developed to support the academic success of the S-STEM scholars. Self-study Guides were developed for: (1) statics and strength of materials, (2) Matlab, and (3) SolidWorks, including material to help students prepare to take the Certified Soldworks Associate (CSWA) exam. Several additional modules that are under consideration. 

 


 

 


Last Modified: 10/11/2021
Modified by: Paula L Sturdevant Rees
